monogr.title: Speculum mundi· Or A glasse representing the face of the world : shewing both that it did begin, and must also end: the manner how, and time when, being largely examined. Whereunto is joyned an hexameron, or a serious discourse of the causes, continuance, and qualities of things in nature; occasioned as matter pertinent to the work done in the six dayes of the worlds creation
monogr.author: Swan, John

lg.l: WHen fresh Aurora first puts forth her head,
And calls bright Sol from out his Eastern bed,
She modestly doth blush; her crimson die
Makes red the verges of the dawning skie:
Procures too hot, to some too cold a day.
So I, with bashfull fear and trembling doubt,
This new-born book into the world send out.
Some (sure) ▪twill please: but never all did any.
I wish the All were few, the Some were many.
But be they as they will; 'tis told me since,
That envie snarleth most at innocence:
And those who least know where to finde th' amisse,
Will soonest brag they could do more then this.
Let them go on; they hurt not me nor mine:
Detracting harms reflect at home in fine.
